A tubal ligation is a safe operation in which a trained health worker opens the skin near the belly button, and then cuts and ties the tubes that carry eggs to the womb. It takes only about 30 minutes.

The operation doesn't change a woman’s menstruation or her ability to have sex or feel sexual pleasure.

Tubal ligation does not protect against STIs, including HIV. You will still need a condom to protect against these infections.

  • Who shouldn’t use it

    A woman should not get a tubal ligation if she thinks she someday may want to give birth to a child.

    A method of sterilization called Essure places a small piece of metal in the Fallopian tubes to create scars that block the release of a woman's eggs. However, this method has generated many serious problems and is no longer available in some countries. No one should use it.
